titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr: Hall arrived here this morning and brought me Letters from America, but not those I have been so long expecting.— Gardner. Walk with him. He dined with me. Evening with him and Frazier. Crafts absent. Saw Hall. Cutting and Foster.

Customary day, dull and dissipated. Pass the morning in sauntering, visiting, or lounging. Write scarce any thing. Dine out almost every day, and pass the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.— Health low— Spirits lower still— This must be reformed almost entirely.

2. Called at the London tavern to make arrangements for our departure to-morrow. Dined at Mr: Pinckney’s. A Spanish Lady there much celebrated for beauty— The Marquis del Campo, who looks like what Mr: Pinckney says he is. Mr: Church &c.

Evening at Drury Lane Theatre. Mrs: Johnson and her Daughter’s at Mrs: Church’s box.— Forbes there.— We went home with the Ladies— Had a partial explanation with one of the Ladies; which gave some satisfaction. Home with Forbes.

3. Between 8 and 9. Sat out with Crafts and Gardner for Cambridge, in a Post Chaise. We arrived there a little after 6 in the Evening. The road has nothing remarkable upon it. The distance about 55 miles.

4. We had some letters to Gentlemen connected with the University, but met with some difficulty to deliver them. At length we found a Mr: Davies, librarian of Trinity College for whom I had a letter from Dr: Pearce, which Mr: Boylston had procured me. The building of King’s Chapel—the library of Trinity College—the public library and the Senate House, with the Commons & School Halls were the principal curiosities that we saw. The first is unquestionably the most deserving of notice, though the other Chapel which we sawhas in a Statue of Sir Isaac Newton by Roubiliac an object in itself more interesting than any thing contained in the other. In the library of trinity College we saw an Egyptian mummy, in a state of greater perfection than any I had ever seen, and also a body taken from an enclosure of that sort, and stript of its covering. It has been thus about 15 years and the body is still in a perfect state of preservation. The teeth, and even the tongue still remain. There are as the librarian told us some curious manuscripts, and among the rest an original of Milton’s Comus, but they can only be shewn by the Master of the College— The Senate House is a very handsome building, and consists only of one room which cost £17000. The public library contains about 30,000 volumes.— A Persian manuscript, another written upon the Papyrus, and a Mass book were shewn us, but the museum is not very large or copious.

We took a walk to a small hill nearby the town, which commands a full view of it as well as of the Cam, the Grant, and the Country all around— The rivers are beautiful but small, and in our Country would scarcely rise above the name of brooks. We pass’d the remainder of the day at our lodgings.

5. Between 7 & 8 this morning we left Cambridge, and returned to town by a different road from that on which we had gone. It is about 7 miles further but is much more pleasant. We arrived at about 5. o’clock. I find my health better for this excursion, and shall endeavour to repeat the experiment.— Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Cards & Music.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Recreation
Courtship and Marriage of JQA and LCA

div.p: 6. Day past almost altogether in idleness. I can scarcely tell how. Evening at Covent-Garden Theatre.— Speculation a new Comedy; and Lock and Key, a new comic Opera. the last much the most amusing of the two.

7. Called on Mr: Morris. Conversation with him upon political subjects. Do not perfectly coincide with him. Mr: Pinckney came in while I was there. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Mr: Murdoch & Captain H. Johnson. Music. Louisa sings prettily
8. Day spent idly as usual. Dined with Mr: Morris. Mr: Pinckney there. Late in the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. No Music.

9. At Mr: Pinckney’s in the forenoon. Conversation with him perhaps too free. After dinner called on Crafts. Went with him to Dibdin’s exhibition. It scarcely equalled my expectations.— Crafts supped with me.

10. Endeavoured to write a little. But find myself overpowered by indolence. Visit from Foster. Dined and passed the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Company considerable.— Excellent Music. The favourite Song.— Caroline very pretty.

11. At Mr: Copley’s to sit for my picture, which Mrs: Copley proposes to send to my mother. Dined and pass’d the Evening at home; the first time for a long while. Scope for reflection. The life I am leading totally dissatisfactory. “Let Housewives make a skillet of my helm.”

12. Dined at Mr: Murdoch’s. Went with Hall. Cutting and Foster. Retired immediately after dinner, and indeed too soon. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Playing cards. Some Music. R. Forbes there. The party dull enough. Louisa 21.

13. Called at Mr: Pinckney’s. He was not at home— At Mr: Rogers’s lodgings. He also was out. Dined at Mr: Erving’s. Sir W. Pepperell, a Mr: Palmer and two other Gentlemen there. Curious imposture in the newspapers, of a pretended preliminary convention for Peace.— G. Erving has intended to go to America.— Evening, an hour or two at Mr Church’s. Mrs: Church unwell.

14. Hall. Crafts. Frazier and Gardner called on me this morning. Walk with the two latter in the Park. Company large. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s, and pass’d the Evening there. A Captain Robins at dinner. Mr: Murdoch in the Evening. Louisa very unwell.
15. At Mr: Copley’s to sit again for my picture. Till between 5 and 6 o’clock— Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Mr: Brooks there. Louisa much better.— Whist.

16. Went to introduce Mr: Hall at Mr: Johnson’s. Conversation with him as we were returning home and afterwards. Dined with Mr: Boylston and his Club at the Crown & Anchor. The company very agreeable. The only objection to his civility is that it is excessive, and makes itself uncomfortable by its ostentation. Mr: Nicholls, a Dr: Greave, a Mr: Heavisides a Surgeon, a Serjeant Marshall, and Hopner the Painter were of the Company and very pleasant. When the companies are entirely English, I find them very tolerable. It is only the half and half societies in which the assimilation becomes impossible.

17. Hall & Gardner called on me this morning. Visit from Mr: Nicholls. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Went with Mrs: Johnson, and her four eldest daughters to Covent-Garden Theatre, where we heard the performance of the Allegro & Penseroso, set to music by Handel. Not much pleased with the music. Displeased with several trifling incidents. Above all dissatisfied with myself for suffering such things to possess an influence over me. Returned with the Ladies & supped. Sullen and silent the whole time. Hall, Foster, Rogers & Forbes at the Theatre with us.

18. Lounge away the day, as usual. Astonished almost as much as mortified at my own imbecillity. Walk with Gardner in Hyde Park.— Dined at Mr: Hope’s. Mr: Pinckney, Mr: Deas Mr: Marshall, Sir Robert Ainsley, Sir F. Baring. Mr: Angerstein, Mr: Sansom, Mr: Smith, and a Mr: Nesbit the company. Marshall could not keep his democratic fixed air within bounds even in this company. The Americans in general that I meet here are the most ill-bred people excepting the English that I ever met with. To suit the conversation to the company is one of the first laws of politeness, and may always be done without any sacrifice of principle too.

19. Again the fore part of the day at Mr: Copley’s sitting for my picture. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Cards with the Ladies: not the best amusement in the world, but they would not give any music.— Play’d however exactly right.— Party, very well upon the whole.

20. Dined at Mr: Brook’s. N. 27. Queen-Street Cheapside. Mr: Johnson and his family, and Mr: Murdoch were there. In the Evening a young templar by the name of Bevil came. Very talkative and inquisitive concerning America. Play’d at Whist. Very successful ill-luck. Incautious as usual. If I were to record every blunder and error that I commit, ending only in my own mortification, I should give almost a true transcript from every scene of company into which I enter.— Solitude is the only source of my valuable enjoyments.— This day was however remarkably pleasant.— That indeed is the greatest objection against it. for what will be to-morrow?

21. What I expected. Mrs: Johnson and her three daughters. Went with them to Hyde-Park. Walk in the park with the young Ladies. Weather not very pleasant. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Evening there. Mr: Murdoch. The day a perfect contrast of yesterday. Nancy very much affected, I know not at what. Louisa pretended a head-ache for the privilege of being cross.

22. Visits in the forenoon. Conversation with Mr: Morris. Do not at all concur in his opinions. Think him more decidedly English, the more I see of him. Dined at Mr: Pinckney’s; by way of celebrating the President’s birth day, he had a numerous party of about 30.— My usual aukwardness about taking a lead—mortified that it was offered me. Table conversation not very instructive or amusing.— Imprudent.— Church talk’d all the time.— Went there with Mr: Johnson, & on breaking up at about 1/2 past 9 he set me down at the London Coffee House, where I stay’d till very late with Frazier, Crafts & Gardner. took leave of Crafts who goes to-morrow morning for Charleston.
23. Fine day. Walk in Hyde Park. Hall dined with me, and we pass’d the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Rogers was there too. Had Music and singing agreeable enough.

24. Writing, and a very little reading. How shall I answer for the present employment of my time?— Dined alone. dull. Frazier, Gardner and Hall pass’d the Evening with me.— Hall stay’d very late.— Burkes new pamphlet, about his pension.

25. Went with Gardner to see Rackstrow’s Museum in Fleet Street. In general but a representation of things seen many times before. Some curious anatomical preparations however— An optical illusion also, contrived as I conclude upon very simple principles. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s with a considerable company. Evening as usual there too. Quite late. Some end must be put to the present state of things. It has got to the end of my patience.
26. Visit from Mr: Boylston in the morning. Day wasted as much as ever. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Mr: Brooks.— Cards and Music. Cloaks for my mother &c.

27. Called at Mr: Johnson’s in the morning. At Mr: Clagget’s to enquire for an opportunity to send or go to Holland. Dined with Mr: Boylston. Mr: Coles there. Evening with Gardner and Frazier and Clarke at the London Coffee House.

28. Was to have walk’d in the Park with the Miss Johnson’s. The weather being bad we could not; but only walk’d rode.— Snow’d a little.— Dined and pass’d the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Very good spirits the former part of the day. Less in the Evening. On returning home found a letter from the Secretary of State.

29. Reflections perplexing. Hall called on me. Walk in the Park with the Miss Johnson’s. Rallied till angry. Hall, Frazier and Gardner dined and pass’d the Evening with me. Frazier went away however, before supper.
